title: Saltillo: Impulsan la movilidad en bicicleta con el foro 'Ciclo comunidad haciendo ciudad'
text:
Saltillo: Impulsan la movilidad en bicicleta con el foro â€˜Ciclo comunidad haciendo ciudadâ€™
â€œCiclo comunidad haciendo ciudadâ€, se denomina el primer foro encaminado a â€œconstruir una polÃ­tica pÃºblica de impulso a la movilidad en bicicletaâ€ en Saltillo.
El evento, al cual han sido convocados ya algunos expertos, se realizarÃ¡ a partir de las 10:00 horas del prÃ³ximo martes 18 de marzo, en las instalaciones de la Unidad Administrativa del Gobierno Municipal de Saltillo.
TE PUEDE INTERESAR: En Saltillo 333 detenidos conmutan cÃ¡rcel por trabajo comunitario
El anuncio del programa tiene lugar a cuatro dÃ­as de haber concluido los foros de consulta ciudadana para integrar el Plan Municipal de Desarrollo 2025-2027.
A la sazÃ³n, el alcalde Javier DÃ­az anunciÃ³, en entrevista para VANGUARDIA, la realizaciÃ³n de proyectos paralelos a la ciclovÃ­a de la capital coahuilense.
Entre los temas de la agenda respectiva, figura, primeramente: â€œActivaciones para impulsar la bicicleta, como un medio alterno de movilidad sostenibleâ€.
Enseguida: â€œActividades para promover el prÃ©stamo de bicis pÃºblicasâ€; â€œPromover el uso de las ciclovÃ­asâ€; ConsolidaciÃ³n y ampliaciÃ³n de la red de ciclovÃ­asâ€.
TambiÃ©n se discutirÃ¡ lo relativo a las â€œRedes de colaboraciÃ³n por una ciudad mÃ¡s sostenible y amigableâ€.
Asimismo, sobre el â€œModelo de interconexiÃ³n con otros medios de transporteâ€, y, como Ãºltimo tema â€œHerramientas tecnolÃ³gicas para apoyo a la movilidadâ€.
Aparecen como auspiciadores el Gobierno del Estado de Coahuila, el Ayuntamiento local, el Instituto Municipal de PlaneaciÃ³n de Saltillo (IMPLAN) y el Instituto Municipal de Movilidad Urbana Sostenible (IMMUS).

author: TechCrunch
title: Identity theft: Seven tips to defeat online fraudsters
text:
dpa international Identity theft: Seven tips to defeat online fraudsters DPA December 29, 2023 at 6:13 AM Â· 3 min read Link Copied Read full article Cybercriminals are constantly coming up with new scams. That means it is all the more important to protect yourself against fraudsters. Franziska Gabbert/dpa
It's not possible to completely prevent personal and sensitive data from falling into the hands of cybercriminals. In the event of a data leak due to a hacker attack, often the only thing left for you to do is change affected passwords as quickly as possible.
However, there's a number of measures you can put in place beforehand, to protect your data from phishing attacks and other scams.
Here are seven tips from the European Consumer Centre:
1. Pass on as little data as possible and always consider what sensitive information is really needed when using an online service. Be suspicious.
2. Don't fall for phishing or smishing messages, attempts to get you to reveal personal data via email or text. Using all sorts of tricks such as sending out fictitious deadlines or threats to block your account, scammers seek to lure you to websites where they can steal your sensitive data such as contact information, credit card numbers or passwords.
3. Instead of clicking in dubious messages that claim to come from legitimate companies, enter the address of the alleged sender manually, log in, and check your customer account to see if there any messages for you there. Alternatively, you can call the supposed sender on their official number and ask them if theyâ€™ve sent you a message.
4. If you get an urgent request from a friend or relative via social media, often connected with a hair-raising or sad story, it's very likely that that person's account has been hacked. So don't react, click on anything or transfer money. Instead contact your friend or relative using another method.
5. If possible, don't pass on copies, photos or scans of your identification documents. If this becomes unavoidable at some point, you should carefully black out all information that isn't required or that's irrelevant, such as your ID number and signature.
You can also add a watermark to the image file using a free image editor such as Gimp. It allows you to add a text band over the image stating the purpose of the copy, the recipient, and the date. The text should also state that the image is a copy.
6. Each online service or account requires a strong, individual password. The easiest way to manage your passwords is a password manager program. Wherever possible, activate two-factor authentication (2FA).
7. In the interests of security, software always needs to be kept updated. That applies to operating systems, programs as well as apps. If updates are available, don't hesitate to install them. Otherwise, possible security gaps remain open to external attacks.
If you notice suspicious movements in one of your accounts, act quickly to prevent further damage. You should report it to the police and inform your bank to block any pending debits.
You should also object to unauthorised credit card payments to receive your money back. If necessary, have accounts or payment cards blocked or apply for a new ID card.
View comments

author: James Desmond; February
title: A Fertile Plot of Land at Franklin First United Methodist Church Is Nurturing Its Neighbors
text:
A Fertile Plot of Land at Franklin First United Methodist Church Is Nurturing Its Neighbors
In 2007, Franklin First United Methodist Church purchased 107 acres on which to build their new church campus. But before the bricks were in place, a pumpkin seed was planted. Those pumpkins brought joy to our children but it seemed God had a bigger plan â€“ to grow a garden. The Giving Garden was then born.
The garden, on a 7-acre portion of the church's land, produces around 20,000 pounds of produce annually, which is then given to nonprofits in the area. The weekly distribution of this produce has enabled Franklin First to learn about their partners and build relationships beyond produce. These relationships include the Franklin Farmers Market, where volunteers gather unsold produce and redistribute it to homes facing food insecurity. They distribute food to
The Healing House, a residential center for women in treatment, where a former resident serves on the board. Volunteers cut hundreds of flowers from the flower and herb garden for arrangements donated to Meal on Wheels.
On Wednesday nights in the summer, the garden hosts an old fashioned potluck where non-gardeners join in the fellowship and might just stay around for a pea shelling good time.
The Giving Garden is solely dependent on the generosity of volunteers from the church and community. Many participants in the Master Gardener program dedicate hours in the garden, as well as high school students needing to fulfill community service hours, youth groups on summer mission, and business organizations wishing to serve the community.
The Giving Garden has evolved and grown since that first pumpkin seed, but it has always been and remains to be â€˜a garden about peopleâ€™ in relationship with each other and our community.
Learn more at
franklinfumc.org or contact the church office at 615.794.2734

author: NewsBreak Original
title: Phil Collins, 73, Reveals 'Drumming Has Taken Its Toll' on His Health in Rare Update
text:
By Marisa Losciale ,
1 hours ago
Phil Collins is laying out his reasons for retiring from the drums two years ago in a raw new interview.
In the documentary Phil Collins: Drummer First , which premiered on Wednesday, the eight-time Grammy winner offered intimate details and new insight into his decades-long career, revealing the real reason he had to step away from the kit.
ðŸ¤©ðŸ¤© SIGN UP for Parade's Trending News newsletter & we'll keep you in the know on the viral pop culture moments & celebrity news everyone is talking about ðŸ—žï¸ðŸ—žï¸
During interviews conducted shortly after Collins announced he was retiring from music in March 2022, he revealed that his decision to put the sticks downâ€”a skill he's practiced since he was about 5â€”was driven by health reasons.
"I'm 71, I've been playing drums all my life," he said in the doc. "To suddenly not be able to do that is a shock."
"Itâ€™s still kind of sinking in a bit," he admitted.
"The drumming has taken its toll on my hands, legs," the "You'll Be in My Heart" artist shared. "I just feel like I've used up all my air miles," Collins, now 73, later joked.
In the Dec. 18 release , the Genesis musician's 23-year-old son, Nic Collins , went into detail about the injuries his father sustained from 50 years of touring. The ailments included back issues over the years followed by a "big surgery on his neck [in 2015] that stemmed from all those years playing drums and bad posture."
It also "caused him to have a drop-foot," Nic said, explaining that his father "has like no sensation" and lacks "control" over his feet, which is why he "can't really play drums" and now walks with a cane.
"If I can't do what I did as well as I did it, I'd rather relax and not do anything," the English musician concluded elsewhere in the documentary. "If I wake up one day and I can hold a pair of drumsticks, then I will have a crack at it."
Phil Collins: Drummer First is now streaming on YouTube.
Next: U2â€™s Larry Mullen Jr. Reveals Health Diagnosis That Makes Him "Look Pained" While Drumming
2

author: David Lynch (KENS 5)
title: Baby babirusa, or deer pig, born at Texas zoo
text: SAN ANTONIO â€” The start of the new year brought another reason to celebrate for the San Antonio Zoo: the facility's first-ever birth of a babirusa, a name that translates literally to "pig deer" in Malay. The baby animal â€“ its name and gender not yet announced â€“ was born to parent babirusas Sula and Kreacher, and represents "a significant milestone for both the zoo and the conservation efforts of this vulnerable species," the zoo said in a statement. Known for their curved tusks, the babirusa is listed by the International Union for Conservation of Nature as "vulnerable," one level away from endangered. One reason for the species' status: Mothers tend to only birth one or two piglets at a time, zoo officials said, while crediting Sula for "her maternal instincts." Native to Indonesia, babirusas can grow to weigh up to 220 pounds as adults, according to the San Diego Zoo. Their "barrel-shaped bodies" are covered with bristly skin that makes them appear hairless, but it's their odd-looking tusks, particularly on male babirusas, that are their most distinctive feature. They can live up to 10 years in the wild, but up to 24 in proper human care. The San Antonio Zoo's initial Instagram post [announcing the babirusa's birth](https://www.instagram.com/p/C1kgmNExP87/?img_index=1) has received dozens of congratulatory comments and thousands of likes, with one user writing: "I don't know what that is, but I love them both." While it's yet to be announced when the baby "deer-pig" will meet human visitors for the first time, the zoo shared footage of the six-day old piglet frolicking around in hay and getting used to his surroundings. "While some may describe these little ones as 'ugly babies,' we can't help but find them irresistibly adorable with their unique and unconventional charm," San Antonio Zoo CEO Tim Morrow said in a release. "We can't wait for the public to fall in love with this precious little babirusa." For the foreseeable future, zoo officials say the animal will spend time bonding with its mother to ensure "a strong foundation for its future." >TRENDING ON KENS 5 YOUTUBE:

organizations.name: international union for conservation of nature

author: @WBRZ
title: Sunday PM Forecast: Rounding out 2023 with great weather
text: Latest Weather Blog Sunday PM Forecast: Rounding out 2023 with great weather Today will feature great weather for any outdoor plans and activities. The start of 2024 is looking unsettled with multiple days of rain chances. Today & Tonight: After hitting the freezing mark this morning, highs will be in the upper 60's in the afternoon and evening. There might be a couple of clouds around, but these will generally be the high cloud variety. Regardless, expect plentiful sunshine. For any staying up to celebrate the New Year, expect mainly clear skies with temperatures in the mid to lower 50's. As we get deeper into the night, cloud cover will begin to increase and spotty showers will be possible. The low temperature is going to be around 48 degrees. Up Next: Monday has been trending a bit drier with less cloud cover. Isolated showers will still be possible but there will most likely be partly sunny skies. Tuesday will be mainly clear with lots of sunshine. The next chance of rain will arrive on Wednesday. Numerous showers will be possible and 1'' rain totals look like they will be common. Rain chances decrease on Thursday, but showers will once again be possible by the start of the weekend. -- Balin Get the latest 7-day forecast and real time weather updates [HERE](https://www.wbrz.com/weather). author: Anna EstartÃºs
title: Dos mil vint-i-quatre
text: Que et mengis els dotze raÃ¯ms a temps i sense ennuegar-te. Que comencis lâ€™any a lâ€™hora que vulguis perÃ² amb un somriure. Que et tornin els diners que tâ€™has gastat en la loteria. Que els Reis et portin la ilÂ·lusiÃ³ de quan tenies cinc anys i els anaves a esperar amb el fanalet encÃ¨s. Que et pugin el sou perquÃ¨ tâ€™ho mereixes i la feina ben feta sâ€™ha de recompensar. Que quan tâ€™aixequis al matÃ­ els genolls no et facin mal. Ni lâ€™esquena, ni el maluc, ni el braÃ§, ni les cervicals (perÃ² que segueixis viu). Que trobis lloc a la platja per posar la tovallola un dia dâ€™agost. Que et preguntin com estÃ s, perÃ² que tâ€™ho preguntin de veritat, amb interÃ¨s. I que tu sÃ pigues respondre de veritat com estÃ s i no et quedis amb el Â«bÃ©, com sempre, anar fentÂ». Que aquella amiga que fa temps que no veus es presenti un dia a la feina per fer-te una abraÃ§ada. Que tâ€™adonis que estaves equivocat en alguna cosa i ho puguis rectificar. Que et diguin que tornes a somriure com ho feies abans. Que aquella pena que penses que mai es curarÃ  es vagi difuminant i, un dia, tâ€™adonis que hi pots conviure. Que tâ€™expliquin histÃ²ries com si fossin contes de les mil i una nits: divertides, entretingudes i sorprenents. Que aquell dia que el mÃ³n se tâ€™ensorra tinguis la certesa que tens a prop teu persones que et recolliran i et faran costat i tâ€™acompanyaran fins que puguis tornar a aixecar-te. Que el dia que el mÃ³n se li ensorri a una persona que estimes sÃ pigues estar al seu costat. Que et mogui mÃ©s lâ€™amor que no pas lâ€™odi. Que, com deia August, el protagonista de Wonder, si has dâ€™escollir entre ser amable i tenir raÃ³, elegeixis ser amable. Que un dilluns puguis entrar mÃ©s tard a treballar. Que gaudeixis dâ€™un vespre sense ningÃº mÃ©s que tu a casa. Que tâ€™atreveixis a fer allÃ² que fa tant de temps que tens ganes de fer perÃ² no acabes de trobar el moment. Que tinguis temps per perdre. Que superis alguna de les teves pors, i que te nâ€™enorgulleixis. Que tinguis converses que tâ€™obrin la ment. Que algÃº, un dia, sâ€™adoni de tots els esforÃ§os que fas per tirar endavant. Que trobis la manera de perdonar allÃ² que fa tant de temps que arrossegues com una llosa. Que trobis aparcament a la primera. Que les males notÃ­cies siguin fÃ cilment relatibitzables. Que algun matÃ­ puguis dormir fins que el cor et digui prou. Que a aquella persona que sempre busca la manera de putejar-te li posin una multa per excÃ©s de velocitat. Que deixis de preocupar-te tant pel quÃ¨ pensaran els altres. Que quan necessitis hora per anar al metge te la donin la mateixa setmana. Que sempre trobis una mÃ  que apreti la teva, encara que sigui en la distÃ ncia. Que sentis orgull dels actes dels teus fills. Que aprenguis dâ€™una vegada a veure el got mig ple enlloc de mig buit (que ja comences a tenir una edat). Que, si tâ€™has de morir, la mort tâ€™enganxi fent la migdiada i somniant coses boniques. Que no tâ€™oblidis de dir Â«bon diaÂ», Â«grÃ ciesÂ», Â«de resÂ» i Â«siusplauÂ», i que no deixis cap Â«tâ€™estimoÂ» per dir. [](https://elmeucompte.diaridegirona.cat/tp/login) [](/)

author: Julia Musto
title: Experts say US plans for lunar nuclear reactor are 'cock-eyed'
text:
Experts say US plans for lunar nuclear reactor are â€˜cock-eyedâ€™
Nasa aims to have the reactor ready for launch by the early 2030s, but little progress has been made
Fast-tracking a Nasa plan to build a nuclear reactor on the moon may sound dubious. Experts say thatâ€™s because it is.
â€œThe whole proposal is cock-eyed and runs against the sound management of a space programme that is now being starved of money,â€ American national-security analyst, nuclear expert and author Joseph Cirincione told the Independent.
Nuclear has been used in space since the 1960s. The US launched its first test reactor into orbit in 1965, and the former Soviet Union has sent up dozens.
Nasa says that a new 100-kilowatt reactor could be used to power a future base at the lunar South Pole, and fuel prospective missions to Mars and beyond. Nuclear would help to fill gaps in solar energy that occur when that side of the moon is in darkness.
The majority of space experts have said that placing a reactor on the moon is possible, so why is Nasaâ€™s current plan â€œcock-eyedâ€? The problem is the proposed timeline.
Interim Nasa administrator Sean Duffy â€“ who also serves as US president Donald Trumpâ€™s transportation secretary â€“ pushed to expedite the project detailed in a memo this week.
Mr Duffy said the administration wanted to have a nuclear reactor ready to launch by 2030. Earlier this year, China and Russia announced a plan to build a nuclear reactor for a lunar base by 2035.
â€œThe first country to do so could potentially declare a â€˜keep-outâ€™ zone, which would significantly inhibit the US from establishing a planned Artemis presence if not there first,â€ Mr Duffy said.
Nasa first announced in 2021 that it would put a reactor on the moon â€œwithin a decadeâ€. In 2024, the agency said that their target date for delivery of a reactor to the launchpad was the early 2030s. But Mr Cirincione â€“ who is vice-chair of the Centre for International Policy, a non-profit that advocates for a peaceful approach to foreign policy â€“ says essentially no progress has been made.
â€œIt was in the last Trump administration that Nasa had put out a press release ... about how theyâ€™re going to develop these small, modular nuclear reactors for use on the moon, and it was going to be ready by 2026,â€ he said.
â€œOh, really? So where is it?â€
He believes it could take up to 20 years for a nuclear reactor on the moon to become a reality. Nasa would need a working launch vehicle, a small and adaptable reactor, and the ability to land on the moon. Right now, the SpaceX Starship is the only option â€“ but it has exploded during several of its test flights.
Accelerating the [Fission Surface Power] programme could come at the expense of â€¦ core elements of Nasaâ€™s public-serving mission
The agency has been working with Boeing on a space launch system â€“ the main competitor to SpaceXâ€™s Starship â€“ but that programme would be cancelled under the Trump administrationâ€™s proposed cuts, which slash 24pc from Nasaâ€™s overall budget.
There are also the scientific and technological advances needed for the nuclear reactors.
They must be able to withstand harsh conditions on the moon, including temperature swings from 121C during the day to -246C at night.
Many scientists and nuclear energy experts have shared in Mr Cirincioneâ€™s scepticism.
Kathryn Huff â€“ a former nuclear energy official at the US department of energy, and a professor at the University of Illinois â€“ wrote in a Bluesky social media post that sheâ€™s not â€œbullishâ€ on â€œunrealistic timelinesâ€.
â€œThe 2030 target does not align well with recent budgetary trends,â€ Dr Huff said in a statement shared by the university. â€œAccelerating the [Fission Surface Power] programme could come at the expense of other critical priorities, including earth science, climate observation and space-based weather forecasting â€“ all core elements of Nasaâ€™s public-serving mission.â€
Alfredo Carpineti, an Italian astrophysicist, wrote in IFLScience this week that the proposal is unfeasible: â€œEven if we allow landing the nuclear reactor on December 31, 2030, the timing is really too short for something that must not have any faults if you want to operate it safely.â€
Others were more optimistic about Nasaâ€™s accelerated timeline.
Sebastian Corbisiero â€“ a senior technical adviser at Idaho National Laboratory who leads the US energy departmentâ€™s space reactor programme â€“ told the Independent that a nuclear reactor on the moon is â€œdoableâ€ by 2030.
â€œNuclear reactor technology has been around for decades, so its well known,â€ he said. â€œSome key differences with a space reactor is that it needs to fit on a rocket â€“ so there are mass and volume requirements â€“ and that the system needs to operate in vacuum, so components will need to be built to survive that environment.â€
